Prentice had run the Journal, notoriously editorializing against Catholics and immigrants, whom he derided as “pestilent foreign swarms,” brewing hatred and hysteria that culminated in the “Bloody Riot” of 1855 in which 22 people in Louisville were killed as they tried to vote.

Watterson’s claim to wartime fame came from editing the Rebel, a newspaper widely read throughout the South and popular with soldiers. But with W.N. Haldeman running the business side, Watterson wrote in favor of such then-radical causes as schools for blacks, which enraged so many readers that he was challenged repeatedly to duels, Joe Creason wrote in a history of the newspaper published on its 100th anniversary.

While Watterson was more enlightened than most Southern Democrats and favored some rights for blacks, he was still a racist who supported segregation, said James C. Klotter, Kentucky’s state historian and professor emeritus at Georgetown College.

And his newspaper was rife with vile slurs. In its first full year, in 1869, it printed 11 stories that used the N-word — though that word was used 292 times during the last year Prentice controlled the blatantly racist Louisville Daily Courier. In a 1903 speech in Chicago, Watterson said that after 30 years of observation, "always directed from a sympathetic point of view, I am forced to agree ... that negro suffrage is a failure because Southern blacks are not equal to it. Where there is one negro fit for citizenship, there are myriads of negroes wholly unfit."

The news reporting under Watterson was weak by modern standards, though coverage of a devastating tornado in 1890 included a list of the damage to every home and building in Louisville. Still, the Courier Journal’s reputation was based entirely on Watterson's editorials.

By the time it celebrated its 25th birthday in 1893, the Courier Journal's editorial page was as widely quoted as any in the country, and Watterson was known as a political kingmaker, Creason wrote.

Like virtually all newspapers of the day, the Courier Journal was affiliated with a political party, and throughout the South it was known as "the Democratic Bible." Watterson himself briefly served in Congress, chaired a party convention and served five times as a delegate to the National Democratic Convention.

But when he opposed Democratic presidential candidate William Jennings Bryan in 1896, infuriated readers and advertisers bailed on the paper, Creason wrote. Only the popularity of the Louisville Times, an afternoon paper founded 12 years earlier by Watterson and Haldeman, saved the company from bankruptcy.

It made its comeback in part through a special newspaper train called "The Owl" launched in 1904 to carry the Courier Journal every day to towns across Kentucky in time for readers to enjoy at breakfast. The move allowed Watterson and Haldeman to boast that the paper had the largest circulation in the South.

Though at heart an isolationist, Watterson recognized in 1913 the menace of an increasingly powerful Germany. And as the war intensified the next year, so did his editorials, which again put the newspaper at risk because many of its major advertisers were of German origin.

But he didn’t retreat, and his editorials calling for the U.S. to declare war on Germany — “To hell with the Hohenzollerns and the Hapsburgs” — he famously wrote, referring to two German royal dynasties — won a Pulitzer Prize in 1918, the newspaper’s first.

By the end of his career, an increasingly cranky Watterson railed against internationalism and women’s suffrage, denouncing “feminine freaks” and “horsey girls” who marched for the right to vote.

Chapter 2: A mysterious death and the Judge Robert Worth Bingham Era

Robert Worth Bingham served only 10 months on the bench, but was forever more prominently known as “Judge Bingham.”

After his first wife, Eleanor, was killed by a speeding commuter train in 1913 (some said she may have thrown herself in front of it), he wed Mary Lily Flagler, the widow of Standard Oil and railroad magnate Henry Flagler, and reportedly the richest woman in America.

When she discovered soon after that she was afflicted with incurable syphilis, to get back in Bingham's good graces, she wrote a $5 million bequest — the equivalent of $90 million today — to Bingham in her will, after he previously renounced any interest in her estate, according to Tifft and Jones in "The Patriarch."

As Mary Lily grew increasingly ill, Bingham "made no attempt to locate the top medical practitioners in the country and rush them to Louisville, something a woman of her means could easily have afforded,” those authors wrote.

When she died and her family learned about his inheritance, they hired the Burns Detective Agency to try to prove she'd been murdered and even secretly exhumed her body. The results of the autopsy were never released.

Klotter, professor emeritus at Georgetown College, writes in his book, “Kentucky: Portrait in Paradox, 1900-1950,” that the “best available evidence suggests no criminality.”

Tifft and Jones, though, say that for the Binghams, the “ignoble roots of their great wealth would become ... 'the madwoman in the attic,' a painful, embarrassing topic rarely discussed."

The bequest made the Binghams one of America's richest families, according to "The Patriarch," though Judge Bingham "was well aware that it had come at a terrible price — a stain on his reputation.”

Just days after collecting the money in 1918, Bingham bought the paper from Haldeman and vowed to use its power "justly and wisely to further the progress of our city, our state, our nation." Bingham later wrote that the paper must "never vary one iota on principle” and that “we are all that stands between the people of Kentucky and the power of those crooked scoundrels to plunder them without restraint.”

And he acted nobly in many ways.

When Henry Ford alleged that Jews were plotting world denomination, Judge Bingham denounced any form of anti-Semitism, and when the Ku Klux Klan burned a cross a half block from the mayor’s house, he lashed out at the organization as “un-American and un-patriotic.”

In 1924, when he was under mounting pressure from Democrats to run for governor, he refused, saying he thought it was improper for a newspaper owner to aspire to elected office.

The paper was hardly great; it thrived on a diet of accident stories and weird features. And while Judge Bingham promised to use the papers to advance the interests of the city, state and nation, he also deployed them "to reward his allies, punish his enemies, and advance his pet political projects,” Tifft and Jones said.

Klotter wrote that an “overtone of superiority” sometimes colored Bingham, especially when it came to Irish Catholic political bosses. “Part of the paradox of Bingham was that this man who often genuinely spoke for the people was himself an aristocrat through and through. His letters tell of his preoccupation with hunting lodges, full bred dogs, carefully crafted guns, English genealogy and ‘the right people.’’’

Still, the pervasive sight of soup lines, apple sellers and the unemployed galvanized the belief of the Binghams in New Deal liberalism, which remained unshaken decades later.

Judge Bingham funneled as much as $50,000 into Franklin Roosevelt’s first presidential campaign, putting him in an elite group of fundraisers that included Joseph P. Kennedy. (That same year, everyone on the paper got a 10 percent pay cut because of the Depression, which didn't sit well, John Herchenroeder, a reporter at the time, later said.)

Judge Bingham hoped to be named secretary of state, but FDR tapped him instead to be ambassador to Great Britain at the Court of St. James's, the most prestigious diplomatic posting.

The stage was set for the transfer of the family business to his son, Barry Bingham Sr.

Chapter 3. Barry Bingham Sr. at the helm

With his father still in England but ailing (he would die the next year of Hodgkin’s lymphoma), Barry Bingham Sr. took over the newspaper, but in an unusual triumvirate that would preside for nearly three decades. Mark Ethridge ran the news side of the paper while Lisle Baker Jr. presided over the business.

That left Bingham free to set policies, including one that required running every letter to the editor not deemed libelous. He also launched an op-ed page that offered a wide range of views.

Few papers published a higher percentage of indignant letters, Creason later wrote, including many that “rip the hide off owner, editors or staff members.”

Bingham made no bones about offending readers or advertisers.

Five years after he took over from his father, on Easter Sunday morning, readers found a full-page ad for the National Committee for Planned Parenthood that said the "first key to national health is birth control.” Bingham’s name was on the top of a list of sponsors.

When angry readers canceled their subscriptions, he gave them their money back but wrote in an editorial that "those objecting to the paper's conduct seem to think a newspaper should not have an opinion which a number of readers do not like. This would mean that a newspaper would have no opinion at all. And having no opinions at all,” he wrote, “is equivalent to having no principles.”

"Bingham Sr. liked bragging about excellence more than bragging about profits, which is what most newspaper owners talk about on the golf course,” Tifft and Jones wrote in "The Patriarch." “He also seriously believed that his newspapers should lead public opinion, not just reflect it."

Before the word “environmentalism” was coined, Bingham’s leadership put the Courier Journal at the forefront of protecting the land.

The newspaper launched the Tom Wallace Farm Forestry Award (named for the then- editor of the Louisville Times) to recognize achievement in reforestation and created a Farm Incentive Program aimed at raising living standards of farm families. By the newspaper’s 100th anniversary, more than 2.5 million people had competed for the $5,000 in prizes offered annually.

The company's reputation for public service ironically rose up to bite it in 1949 when it tried to sell the family-held WHAS Radio, Creason wrote. The Federal Communications Commission refused to OK the sale, saying the company's record for public service was too valuable to risk losing the station to another owner.

The Courier Journal’s most prolonged environmental crusade was its two-decade battle against unregulated strip mining, which despoiled mountains, streams and forests. The newspaper's aggressive reporting and editorials finally produced tough federal legislation and brought the newspaper its fourth Pulitzer Prize, in 1967, for public service.

But it was in the field of civil rights that the Courier Journal took its strongest stand, pressing for integrated schools, equal job opportunities, open housing and other measures, Tifft and Jones wrote in "The Patriarch."

Within days of the Supreme Court's landmark Brown v. Board of Education decision in 1954 that segregation of public schools was unconstitutional, the papers began crusading for peaceful enforcement of the law. Bingham Sr. served on a mayoral committee to smooth the path for integrated facilities, making dozens of visits to theaters and restaurants to try to persuade owners to open their doors to blacks.

But while the newspapers supported civil rights, Bingham Sr. and his wife, Mary, affectionately referred to the large staff of blacks at Melcombe, their estate, as "our dear nigs," according to "The Patriarch." Mary notoriously insisted on draining the pool after one of her sons invited a black boy to swim in it, journalist Marie Brenner wrote in “House of Dreams: The Bingham Family of Louisville.”

And through 1942, the newspaper ran a cartoon called "Hambone Says" that portrayed African-Americans with stereotypical drawings, used stereotypical diction and the N-word.

Although the Louisville papers hired their first black reporter in 1961, black people continued to be banned from wedding photos and society columns in the women’s section. And the papers insisted on calling Muhammad Ali by his given name, Cassius Clay, for six years after he adopted his Muslim moniker in 1964.

Bingham Sr. had other shortcomings. He involved himself and his paper in politics and government in a way that would make modern-day editors blush. Like his father, Bingham Sr. thought it was wrong for a publisher to run for office, but he saw nothing wrong with palling around with presidential candidate Adlai Stevenson on a worldwide fact-finding trip. "It didn't seem strange or peculiar," he said later to Tifft and Jones, admitting it would have evoked a furor later.

In 1959, he asked John Ed Pearce to assist Wilson Wyatt, the newspaper’s outside counsel, in his campaign for governor, while Pearce remained on the staff as an editorial writer. When Wyatt lost to Bert Combs, Combs persuaded Bingham to let Pearce serve on a state board to oversee expansion of the parks. Staff members protested that it was a conflict of interest.

Pearce also wrote speeches for Combs, which Pearce later realized was a mistake. “I thought I was obeying my publisher,” he wrote in his memoirs. “But in small ways the paper suffered, in that readers had but one more reason to suspect it was guilty of a conflict of interest.”

Combs’ adversary, Happy Chandler, would say: “Pearce will write him a speech and Combs will stumble through it and Pearce will race back to Louisville and write an editorial about what a fine speech it was. You could say it is the shortest double play in history: Pearce to Combs to Pearce.”

But the newspaper was on the brink of a new era. Mary and Barry’s firstborn son, Worth, a dashing Harvard graduate who had served three years in the Navy, was being groomed to run it. He prepped first as a reporter in Minneapolis and San Francisco before joining the Courier Journal’s Washington bureau, then returned home to Louisville to apprentice as assistant to serve the publisher.

On July 12, 1966, driving to the beach on Nantucket Island with his wife, Joan, and daughter Clara, he had placed an 8-foot surfboard across the width of the car, sticking out the windows on both sides. One end hit a parked car and the board swung around and hit Worth in the back, killing him instantly. He was 34.

He was the second son to die tragically. Two years earlier, Jonathan had climbed a utility pole to tap electricity at Melcombe, to light up a barn for a reunion of his old Cub Scout troop. When he tried to make the connection, he was electrocuted. He was 22 and the youngest of five children — three boys and two girls.

Chapter 4: 'Mr. Clean'

Worth’s death haunted Barry Jr., as he was almost universally known, Alex Jones later wrote in a New York Times story about the Binghams that won a Pulitzer Prize.

George Barry Bingham Jr., the second-born son, found himself unexpectedly forced to assume stewardship of the papers, a role intended for his older brother. Nine days after Worth’s death, Barry Jr. returned to Louisville from Washington, D.C., where he worked as a documentary filmmaker and took the title that had been briefly held by his brother, assistant to the publisher.

Five years later, in 1971, when his father retired, Barry Jr. assumed the titles of editor and publisher.

He discovered such rampant conflicts of interest that "it would make a harlot blush,” he later told Tifft and Jones. The farm editor was plugging his tractor dealership in the paper; a photographer was snapping extra pictures for the local gas and electric company; and reporters were taking free gifts, from theater tickets to bottles of whiskey.

Barry Jr. initiated ethics rules that ended those practices and set the standards for the rest of the industry. Some of them bordered on the absurd. He insisted that his papers pay for review copies of books provided to news outlets for free, which irritated publishers because they had no way to account for the reimbursements. The Wall Street Journal dubbed him “Mr. Clean.”

Under his leadership, the newspapers won three Pulitzer prizes in 15 years and published award-winning stories that prompted reforms in coal-mine safety, the nursing home industry, coroners’ death investigations and the policing of negligent doctors.

But Tifft and Jones said his greatest legacy was his demand for ethics, and “in many ways, it was a more enduring contribution than anything his grandfather or father had accomplished."

In the latter 1970s, though, rising gas prices, the lingering resentments over busing and the rise of the Lexington Herald-Leader began pressing in on the Courier Journal’s dominance.

An internal review by news critic Bob Schulman found that the flagship paper was often out of touch. Stories rambled on endlessly, pocketbook issues were all but neglected, and arts stories were too highbrow to appeal to a wide audience. When Elvis came to town, for instance, the Courier Journal didn’t even assign a reviewer to cover the concert.

Schulman concluded that if the Courier Journal were a person, it would be a “serious, often stuffy, upper-crust schoolmaster who wears his hair long and occasionally plucks a guitar to show he’s with it.”

After taxes, the company barely broke even. An in-house study recommended cutting the news hole and reporter staff by 5 percent and reducing the number of pages of the paper circulated to distant counties. In an editorial in 1976 explaining changes at the papers, Barry Jr. conceded “the hard reality is that the newspaper must change to match the taste of communities they cover ... or die a lingering and needless death.”

Chapter 5: The fall of the house of Bingham

The first signs of a schism between Barry Jr. and his two sisters — Sallie, an author and feminist, and Eleanor — emerged in 1979, in a story in Louisville Magazine about the sisters titled “Bingham Black Sheep.” They called him sexist, even though five years earlier he’d named the first woman managing editor at a major daily paper and helped launch the downtown Jefferson Club, which admitted women and blacks who private clubs turned away.

The sibling rivalry boiled over in 1984 when he kicked his wife, Edith, and both sisters off the company board in favor of professional directors. "If you can't read a budget," he said at the time, "what in the hell are you doing approving one?" He later complained to Fortune magazine about board meetings where “my wife was doing needlepoint, one sister was addressing Christmas cards and another didn't bother to attend."

Advisers warned him the move would backfire, and it did. Sallie announced she would sell her 15 percent stake in the company to an outside buyer if the family refused to meet her price. She demanded $42 million. The family countered with $25 million. Then she dropped her demand to $32 million. Barry’s financial advisers urged him to raise his offer to $28 million, but he refused, saying it would throw the company too far into debt.

Barry Bingham Sr., then 79, threw up his hands and announced the company would sell all its holdings.

To maintain the newspapers’ value, management, which had always vigorously supported organized labor on its editorial pages, hired a consultant to break a nascent effort to organize a local chapter of the Newspaper Guild.

The announcement of the sale was posted Jan. 9, 1986, on a newsroom wall, in competing memos. Bingham Sr. called the decision an “unwelcome duty” but said “times change.” Barry Jr. called it a “betrayal," "irrational" and "ill advised."

The staff and public largely blamed Sallie for the sale, but Tifft and Jones in "The Patriarch" cited multiple culprits, including Barry Jr.

“He did not understand he was the head of a republic, not a dictatorship, and that much of his power derived from the confidence the rest of the family had in him,” they said. “He clung to the rigid assumption that his authority should be almost total.”

All told, the Binghams collected $448 million for the newspapers; radio and TV stations; Standard Gravure, the family's printing company; and other assets. Gannett, the nation’s largest newspaper chain, put in the winning bid for the newspapers, which it acquired on July 14, 1986, for $306.9 million.

“I hope Gannett executives will pardon my candor when I say this is a day I had hoped never to live to see,” Barry Jr. said in a statement.

In his final words to the staff on July 14, 1986, he said: “Preserve this shrine of quality and integrity, which I have tried to help you build over the past 15 years. May you prosper and do great things. And may God’s peace be with you always. Farewell.”

Chapter 6: A new owner

In his first meeting with Courier Journal employees, Gannett chairman Al Neuharth promised to use “our substantial Gannett resources, money, talent and equipment to first preserve and then try to enhance the traditions of journalistic excellence that you have established.”

But by the next year, according to "The Patriarch," Gannett established a 25 percent after-tax profit goal for the newspapers, compared with 12.6 percent in 1984, according to figures released at the time by Henry Ansbacher Inc., an investment banker.

It closed the Louisville Times in 1987, which Barry Jr. had already merged with the morning paper. The combined staff, which had 337 news employees before the merger, was trimmed to about 240 a year later after duplicative positions were eliminated. It now has about 60, according to the staff directory posted online.

The Courier Journal also eventually closed bureaus in Washington, Indianapolis, Southern Indiana and across Kentucky; ended home circulation in Eastern and Western Kentucky; and did away with its magazine, book page, Neighborhoods sections and stand-alone Business and Metro sections.

In an interview for his obituary, Barry Bingham Jr., who died in 2006, said he was saddened by the dismantling of the paper's bureaus and its shrinking news pages. “The Courier Journal is not what it used to be,” he said, "but on the other hand, journalism in America is not what it used to be.”

Consider this:Amid radical change, the Courier Journal is still proud and powerful

Still, the Courier Journal expanded its reach when it took its first steps online in 1997, and later added photo galleries, videos and livestream coverage of news events and editorial board interviews with political candidates to its website, courierjournal.com.

In 2002, Gannett poured $85 million into a new production plant and press that allowed more use of color and had twice the printing speed. (The plant now prints the Lexington Herald-Leader, Evansville Courier Press and the Midwest edition of the New York Times, as well as the Courier Journal.)

And while its reporting ranks shrunk, the newspaper continued to win awards and tackle tough stories.

In the year it was sold, two of its reporters won the George Polk Award for national reporting for stories about an air crash that killed 248 soldiers returning from a peacekeeping mission to Fort Campbell and the poor safety records of charter carriers hired by the Pentagon.

In 1989, the newspaper won a Pulitzer Prize, its ninth, for coverage of the 1988 bus crash near Carrollton, Kentucky, in which 27 people, 24 of them children, died in the worst drunken-driving crash in U.S. history.

Also:30th anniversary is 'a deep reminder' of deadly Carrollton bus crash

In 1999, the Courier Journal and two of its reporters won the Worth Bingham Prize for investigative reporting and a George Polk Award for “Dust, Deception and Death,” a series that revealed widespread cheating on coal-dust tests in Kentucky and other states. And in 2003, another pair of reporters won a Polk Award for “Justice Delayed, Justice Denied,” a series on how litigants and others suffered because of chronic delay in the courts in Bullitt County. A series on delays in the courts statewide was a Pulitzer finalist.

The staff rose to cover tragic national stories, including the 1989 mass shooting at Standard Gravure in which a disgruntled former employee killed eight workers, then himself; another in 1997 at Heath High School in West Paducah, in which a 14-year-old opened fire on fellow students in a prayer circle, killing three and wounding five others; and yet a third in January 2018 at Marshall County High School in Benton, in which a 15-year-old killed two fellow students and wounded 14 others.

Its reporters told the story of the decline of Big Tobacco; the rise of addiction to OxyContin and opioids; and the abuse and neglect of children and the state's failure to prevent it.

They told how the Archdiocese of Louisville shamelessly moved priests and other employees from parish to parish after they abused children and adults, and ultimately paid a $23.7 million settlement to try to make amends for it.

Read this:Sex abuse survivors don't trust priests — or Louisville's archbishop

They chronicled the rise of gay rights, starting with the hard-won Louisville Fairness Ordinance, which protects rights in employment and housing, and the historic 2015 Supreme Court ruling arising in part from a Kentucky case — the aptly titled Love v. Beshear — that established same-sex marriage as a constitutional right.

Its reporters have uncovered corruption in City Hall, Frankfort and at the University of Louisville, where its stories about excessive pay and secrecy helped force the resignation of President James Ramsey.

The Courier Journal also has covered good news, of course, such the Kentucky Derby and associated festivities; the rise of the state's bourbon-related tourist industry; Louisville's burgeoning food culture; the opening of Louisville Slugger Field, the Louisville Slugger Museum & Factory and KFC Yum Center, all downtown; and what was known until recently as Papa John’s Cardinal Stadium, just south of the University of Louisville’s campus.

The newspaper has chronicled championships of U of L and UK on the fields and the courts, as well as scandals off them. It broke the story of how coach Rick Pitino had sex with a woman at a Louisville restaurant, then paid her to get an abortion, as well as her conviction for trying to extort money, cars and houses from him. And it documented the more recent misconduct — including the shameful providing of prostitutes and strippers to recruits and players — that led to the ouster of Pitino and athletic director Tom Jurich.

And of course the Courier Journal covered politics, including the election of Kentucky’s first Republican in 32 years, Ernie Fletcher; the rise of the next one, Matt Bevin, a dozen years later; and the GOP takeover of both houses of the state legislature, which allowed the passage of the party’s long-sought right-to-work legislation and the repeal of the prevailing wage.

Gannett initially brought in an outsider as top editor, Michael Gartner, the respected former editor and president of the Des Moines Register, which Gannett also had acquired. But after only one year, it put the Courier Journal in the hands of a home-grown talent, David Hawpe.

Hawpe knew the state intimately; he was often teased for claiming to be from both Louisville’s South End and the mountains of Eastern Kentucky, even when he lived in Anchorage or Crescent Hill.

He ran the news operation for 10 years until April 1, 1996, when Gannett brought in another outsider, Mark Silverman, the architect of a corporate program called News 2000, which focused on community news and diversity. In a 13-month stint, Silverman vigorously enforced Gannett policies, including limiting the number of stories that "jumped" off page one, and was notoriously tough on his editors, once asking a sports editor, “Are you being insubordinate, or are you just incompetent?”

Silverman, who went on to run Gannett papers in Detroit and Nashville and is now retired, said in an interview that he was sent to Louisville to serve as a bridge between the Bingham and Gannett eras, but "to be honest with you, I didn't handle it all that well. I was a bit of a jerk sometimes."

Silverman was succeeded by the Courier Journal’s first African-American editor, Bennie Ivory, a founding editor of USA TODAY who had run Gannett papers in Jackson, Mississippi, and Wilmington, Delaware. He launched the Courier Journal’s first investigative unit and led expensive, yearslong court battles to make public records of the University of Louisville Foundation and University of Louisville Hospital. The newspaper’s outside First Amendment counsel, Jon Fleischaker, called him “a terrific force for openness.”

Ivory also reluctantly shuttered the paper’s bureau system, including its storied bureau in Hazard. "We were not growing in the state, and there's real potential to grow our suburban market," he was quoted saying in his own paper. "But we're not abdicating our responsibility for the big-impact stories. If there's a coal-mining disaster, we'll be there."

Ivory, who retired in 2013, was followed by Neil Budde, a Western Kentucky University alumnus who had previously been a reporter and editor at the Courier Journal, then helped launch the Wall Street Journal online. He was hired with the goal of expanding the news organization's digital and online presence but was forced out after three years.

Next came Joel Christopher, in 2016, who remains as executive editor but now works under Editor Richard Green, whom Gannett appointed in May to oversee the Courier Journal, courierjournal.com and news operations at its other papers in the Midwest.

An Ohio native whose wife is from Louisville, Green, introducing himself in a column in June, vowed an “unflinching commitment to the First Amendment, to investigative journalism and to finding and then telling — through a host of new and exciting ways — the stories of Kentucky’s people, places, problems and potential in our 120 counties, starting right here in the state’s most-populated city and county.”

Green conceded that the news business has been “confronted by change and challenge this past decade.” But he promised to “fight like hell to protect and prioritize investigative journalism our community, state and nation so desperately needs in these polarizing times.”

And he said, “We will kick over rocks, ask the tough questions, shine a bright light in those dark, unsavory recesses of government, protect Kentucky’s most vulnerable and celebrate the many good things that happen along this stretch of the muddy Ohio.”

London CNN —

UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has survived a confidence vote by members of his own party – but the final count of lawmakers who rebelled against him was far higher than his supporters expected.

After a tidal wave of recent criticism – which included illegal, lockdown-breaking parties thrown in his Downing Street offices – Johnson squeaked by with 211 votes to 148 in a secret ballot on Monday.

The government hailed the result, with Johnson saying he thought “this is a very good result for politics and for the country.”

“I think it’s a convincing result, a decisive result, and what it means is that as a government we can move on and focus on the stuff that really matters to people,” Johnson said.

Yet his thin margin of victory means that 41% of his own parliamentary party refused to back Johnson, three years after he led the Conservative Party to a landslide victory in the last general election.

Voting began at 6 p.m. (1 p.m. ET) Monday after Johnson urged Conservative lawmakers to back him and reminded them that he had led the party to its biggest electoral win in 40 years, according to a letter he wrote seen by PA Media.

The large rebellion by his lawmakers will leave Johnson’s reputation diminished and could damage his ability to push through legislation. Disappointing results for the party in upcoming polls could also heap more pressure on Johnson, as Conservatives face two difficult parliamentary by-elections in late June.

Despite the victory, the opposition Labour Party has said that by hanging onto power this time, Johnson makes the prospect of an early election even more likely. Labour Party leader Keir Starmer predicted to LBC that Monday’s vote would mark “the beginning of the end” of the Prime Minister’s political career – no matter which way the vote went.

“If you look at the previous examples of no confidence votes, even when Conservative Prime Ministers survive those … the damage is already done,” the opposition leader told LBC Monday. “Usually, they fall reasonably swiftly afterwards.”

Following the vote, Starmer said Johnson was “utterly unfit for the great office he holds” and accused Conservative lawmakers of ignoring the British public. “The Conservative Government now believes that breaking the law is no impediment to making the law.”

Scotland’s First Minister Nicola Sturgeon called Johnson an “utterly lame duck” on Twitter following the vote.

“That result is surely the worst of all worlds for the Tories. But much more importantly: at a time of huge challenge, it saddles the UK with an utterly lame duck PM,” Sturgeon said in a tweet on Monday night.

Video Ad Feedback 'No way out': Commentator predicts Boris Johnson's future 02:10 - Source: CNN

Johnson’s predecessor Theresa May was the last sitting British leader to face a no-confidence vote from their own party. May narrowly survived that vote, which had been called amid months of chaos over her doomed Brexit deal – but she ultimately resigned months later.

Monday’s vote was triggered after more than 54 lawmakers sent letters to the chair of the Tory backbench 1922 committee, following a tidal wave of criticism over a number of scandals that have engulfed Johnson’s premiership for several months.

Last month, a damning report by a senior civil servant found a culture of partying and socializing among Johnson’s staff during Covid-19 lockdown, while millions of Britons were banned from seeing their friends and relatives.

The so-called Partygate scandal plunged his approval ratings and sparked a drumbeat of dissatisfaction among several of his backbenchers. But Johnson has also been criticized for his response to a cost-of-living crisis, and his party suffered heavy losses at local elections in May.

Under Conservative party rules – which can be changed at any time – a leader who survives a confidence vote is safe from such a challenge for 12 months.

But with only 58.6% of Conservative MPs backing Johnson on Monday, the Prime Minister suffered a worse result than his predecessor May, who had the support of 63% of her lawmakers in a much smaller parliamentary party when she faced a confidence vote in 2018.

Despite the worse performance, Johnson insisted it was an “extremely good” result, saying he was not interested in a snap election to gain a new mandate from the public.

London CNN —

UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced his resignation as Conservative Party leader Thursday, bringing his scandal-plagued tenure to an end after less than three years.

Johnson was left with little choice but to step down after several high-profile members of his cabinet resigned in protest this week over his handling of misconduct allegations related to government officials. Dozens more members of his government have also quit.

Johnson was ultimately undone by his response to fallout from the resignation last Thursday of deputy chief whip Chris Pincher, amid allegations Pincher had groped two guests at a private dinner the night before. While he did not admit the allegations directly, Pincher said in a letter to Johnson last week that “last night I drank far too much” and “embarrassed myself and other people.” Other historical allegations of misconduct by Pincher emerged in the ensuing days.

Johnson initially denied being aware of some of those allegations, but ultimately the Prime Minister was forced to admit he had been briefed years before and apologize for his decision-making.

It was the final straw for many political allies who had supported Johnson through crisis after crisis over the years. In recent months the Prime Minister had been facing a barrage of criticism from all sides over his conduct and that of his government, including illegal, lockdown-breaking parties thrown in his Downing Street offices, for which he and others were fined.

Johnson faced numerous other scandals that hit his standing in the polls – despite his 80-seat landslide general election victory just two and a half years ago. These include accusations of using donor money inappropriately to pay for a refurbishment of his Downing Street home and whipping lawmakers to protect a colleague who had breached lobbying rules.

Two weeks ago, the Conservatives lost two key by-elections – results that were blamed on Johnson personally.

In early June, he survived a confidence vote, but the final count of his lawmakers who rebelled against him was higher than his supporters expected: 41% of his own parliamentary party refused to back him.

That vote was triggered after months of speculation over Johnson’s future. The so-called “Partygate” scandal, which saw Johnson found guilty of breaking his own Covid-19 laws by attending a gathering to celebrate his birthday at a time when such events were banned, has dogged Johnson since the news broke late last year.

A controversial rise

With the possible exception of his hero, Winston Churchill, Johnson was perhaps the most famous politician to enter Downing Street as Prime Minister, having forged a successful career as a journalist, novelist, TV personality and London mayor in the preceding decades.

He was a populist before populists really existed. His controversial comments – comparing Muslim women who wear face coverings to letterboxes, or calling gay men “bum boys” to name but two – appalled many. But he got away with his Lothario image, the public seemingly happy to accept his alleged affairs and love child. It seemed that Johnson could essentially laugh his way through any problem.

Yet, for all his ambition and charisma, the job of Prime Minister seemed out of reach for most of his adult life. Those who know Johnson personally say that he loathed the fact that many in the British Conservative elite saw him as a useful campaigning tool but more of a comedian cheerleader than a serious statesman.
